article.title: Extremely Red Submillimeter Galaxies: New z> 4-6 Candidates Discovered using ALMA and Jansky VLA

choices: A comparison of the redshift distribution of lensed and unlensed SMGs.
A comparison of the submm/mm/radio colors of ASXDF1100.053.1 and 231.1 with known SMGs at various redshifts.
A demonstration of the strong negative K-correction in the Rayleigh-Jeans tail of SMG dust SEDs.
A comparison of the radio/submm photometric redshifts of ASXDF1100.053.1 and 231.1 with their spectroscopic redshifts.

multiple_choice_question.text: What wavelength range is represented by the RGB image (top right) in Figure 2?
choices: Optical/near-IR
Mid-IR
Submillimeter
Radio

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be inferred about ASXDF1100.231.1 from the multi-wavelength images shown in Figure 3?
choices: It is clearly detected in the Herschel SPIRE images at 250, 350, and 500 μm.
It is a strong radio source, easily detected in the VLA 1.4 GHz image.
It appears to be a single, unblended SMG with no signs of multiplicity.
It has a counterpart in the Spitzer IRAC images, but it is not detected in the optical bands.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the multi-variate Gaussian probability distribution, Φ, in Formula (1) represent?
choices: The probability density distribution for the dust temperature of an SMG.
The likelihood of observing a particular set of submm/mm/radio colors for an SMG at a given redshift.
The distribution of redshift uncertainties for radio/submm photometric redshift estimates.
The survival function used to account for upper limits in flux densities when estimating photometric redshifts.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from the redshift probability density distributions shown in the middle panel of Figure 4?
choices: The most likely redshift for both ASXDF1100.053.1 and 231.1 is z ~ 2.
The radio/submm photometric redshifts of ASXDF1100.053.1 and 231.1 are significantly higher than their optical/near-IR photometric redshifts.
The inclusion of SCUBA-2 850-μm data reduces the uncertainty in the redshift estimates for both SMGs.
The low probabilities of low-redshift solutions for both SMGs are due to the prevalence of cold dust SEDs in the sample used for the analysis.
